comments:

but old editor not closed and new one not opened.

using 3.0 'stable'.

Do you have steps to reproduce this ?

Exception happens in SWT/StyledText. Moving...

right-click on package explorer the class to rename.
choose the new name in dialog.
click ok.

FH to determine why StyledText calling GC.setBackground with null.

SSQ and FH to discuss why GC.setBackground doesn't restore teh default color 
when null is passed in.

Dirk, there is no way StyledText is calling GC#setBackground(null).
If that was true the exception would be ERROR_NULL_ARGUMENT.
ERROR_INVALID_ARGUMENT means that the color passed to GC#setBackground has 
been disposed. Check GC line 2260:
if (color.isDisposed()) SWT.error(SWT.ERROR_INVALID_ARGUMENT);

Somebody is setting a color in the styledtext and disposing this color while 
the styledtext is still using it.

Moving back.
Moving to JDT/Text. This seems to be editor related then.

I cannot reproduce this. Could you provide more detailed steps. Including the
file that you want to rename and whether you select the CU or the class when
renaming.

see comment #2.
'package explorer' view context menu.

What is 'CU'?

This bug is about a month old, there is no way I can find that file. Lot of
water under bridges since that 'epoch'...

>What is 'CU'?
= compilation unit

In the Package Explorer it looks like this:
+pack
   + A.java (the CU / file)
      A (the type)

Do you select A.java or A?
Also, can you reproduce the problem?

I don't have anything else below the java file.
I use the outline view for browsing members to avoid what I consider pollution
to the package view... ;-)

So the answer is I right-clicked the java file.
I could reproduce over and over at that time. Since I avoided the bug until now,
my code base change a lot, and current attempts to reproduce the bug don't succeed.

But I got another similar problem, right this morning, while
trying to refactor-rename a package. See error below.

Hypothesis: is eclipse sensitive to file locks, if any?
Could eclipse lock files, but mistakenly lock itself out upon refactoring
operations?

I know win2000 is sometimes holding obsolete handles, until reboot.
I understand that any attemps to rename/delete a directory that is the current
directory of one or more process, the attempt will fail.

That would explain the package renaming, although I verified that no process is
pointing to it as I am aware, but would not explain why a single class rename
failed, since no directories are involved (and at that time, I checked that no
editors were open on that file.)
